title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the risks law enforcement officers face daily, the increase in violent crime and drug use, and the lack of adequate support from the Federal Government. The Presidential Commission on Law Enforcement and the Administration of Justice of 1965 highlighted various issues affecting law enforcement, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. A review twenty-five years later would help evaluate current problems in law enforcement, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. A comprehensive study of law enforcement issues, including the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers, working conditions, and responsibility for crime control, would assist in redefining relationships between the Federal Government, the public, and law enforcement officials. Establishment of the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" (referred to as the "Commission") with duties outlined. The Commission will study and recommend changes related to law enforcement agencies at all levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, and research/training status. The Commission will study the intelligence, infrastructure, procedures, research, training, equipment, resources, cooperation, responsibility, and impact of law enforcement agencies at all levels. The Commission will consult with law enforcement officers, local officials, and community leaders nationwide to gather information on important law enforcement issues, including the impact of the criminal justice system on law enforcement. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including seven individuals from national law enforcement organizations. These members will be appointed by various leaders in Congress and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members, including seven individuals from national law enforcement organizations. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in Congress and the President. Specific appointments are designated by different leaders, including the Speaker of the House, the majority and minority leaders of the Senate and House, and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in Congress and the President, including academic experts in law enforcement, Members of the House of Representatives, and individuals from federal law enforcement agencies and the Department of Justice. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in Congress and the President, including individuals from the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Justice, as well as representatives from State or local governmental entities appointed by the Senate Majority Leader and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Comptroller General serves in an advisory capacity and oversees the methodology of the Commission's study. Members of the Commission select a chairperson from among themselves and receive no compensation. The Comptroller General oversees the methodology of the Commission's study. Members select a chairperson and receive no additional compensation. Members will be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services as requested. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and secure information from federal agencies. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. Additionally, the Commission can accept gifts and donations. The Commission has the authority to request information from federal agencies, accept gifts and donations, and use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. The Commission will submit a report with findings and proposals to Congress within eighteen months of its appointment. It will cease to exist sixty days after submitting the report. Upon submitting its report, the Commission will cease to exist after sixty days. Title XXXIV of the Crime Control Act of 1990 and title II, section 211 B of the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1991 will be repealed.
